Award.AwardTitle: Investigation on the Improvement of Success of R&D Funding at Hispanic Serving Institutions and the Effect on Educational Experience of Undergraduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this proposal is to improve undergraduate student education in STEM at Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs). This will be accomplished by: i) identifying common issues that prevent HSIs from obtaining extramural funding which may impact student retention and graduation rate; ii) connecting STEM educators at HSIs throughout the country through the creation of a centralized faculty development network website: and iii) providing access to available resources recently supported by NSF. At the core of the project is a symposium that will be held at the University of Texas El Paso centering on the improvement of HSIs R&D funding rates. The outcome of this work will result in better trained faculty, establishment of communication network between HSIs around the country, and documented resources for faculty to use. The proposed work will contribute to the strengthening of HSIs capacity for performing high quality research in various STEM disciplines and providing research opportunities for undergraduate students. This will increase participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields and contribute to the building of a competent STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this project was to improve undergraduate student education at Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs). This was and is being accomplished by A) identifying common issues that prevent HSIs from obtaining extramural funding which may impact student future job prospects and success, B) educating HSIs through the creation of a faculty development website, and C) providing faculty access to available resources recently supported by NSF and host a symposium that will center on the improvement of HSIs R&D funding rates.

Various institutions were contacted and surveys distributed to faculty at a wide number of HSIs in order to acquire more information on barriers HSI faculty face in obtaining funding, which prevents them from supporting undergraduate researchers. A survey was sent to over 500 faculty at HSIs located in Texas, New Mexico and California, 26 responses were received. Some notable reasons documented restricting HSIs from successfully competing for funding included: faculty course load too high, lack of competitive research facilities, and students not-prepared. Reasons that were not impeding faculty to obtain research funding were faculty retention and recruitment or a lack of development workshops at their home institutions. Other results will be reported in a journal publication. 

As part of developing a partnership with HSIs a faculty development website was also brought online. The goal of the website is to empower faculty to promote effective research to enhance their teaching and learning practices at HSIs. As part of the HSI sharing site, a set of materials have been posted online. This currently includes recently funded NSF proposal. This information along with webinar materials was provided by Southern University and A&M College and Louisiana State University. The webinar content has been made available with permission from the PI of another project and links to the files have been posted on the website and made accessible to any faculty interested. Another resource tool includes materials from a NSF grant writing workshop recently hosted by Southern University and A&M College with permission from the PI of that project. The materials available from the workshop include a proposal strategy building PowerPoints and presentations where tips are given to improve the overall content. Some results from mock review panels with feed back on strengths and weaknesses are also included. PowerPoint presentations from the workshop from NSF Program Managers provide insight into key proposal elements.

Funding from this project also allowed for ten faculty participants to be selected and sent to a NSF Workshopin Arlington, VA. The names and institutions and participants represented at the symposium are listed elsewhere but included faculty from Texas, California, Florida, and New Mexico. During the workshop, topics such as proposal writing techniques, general skills that can be used on proposals for NSF (as well as other agencies), and specific program areas were addressed. The outcome helped participating faculty to not only compete with traditional universities but also amongst other HSIs. The workshop was very interactive, having participants review, draft and comment on peer developed proposals and proposal abstracts. The workshop also allowed for participants to meet with and discuss potential ideas with NSF Program Directors.

This project has created a broad impact by strengthening HSIs capacity for performing high quality research in various STEM disciplines. Increased R&D funding at HSIs is one factor contributing to higher graduation rates of Latinos at HSIs. For example, five of the top ten R&D funded institutions ranked in among the best in terms of graduation rates of Hispanics.
